block.p: Weeks
This
Last
On
Week
Week
List
Fiction

THE REMNANT, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $24.99.) The 10th volume of the ''Left Behind'' series, in which the forces of good battle the forces of evil after the rapture of the saved. (+)
THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A 14-year-old girl looks down from heaven as she describes what happens in the aftermath of her kidnapping and murder.
ELEVENTH HOUR, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam, $24.95.) When his identical twin brother, a priest, is murdered, an F.B.I. agent searches for the killer.

THE BEACH HOUSE, by James Patterson and Peter de Jonge. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) After his brother drowns in East Hampton, a law student seeks revenge on the powerful people who he thinks are responsible.
SUNSET IN ST. TROPEZ, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Surprises await a group of friends who decide to spend August on the Riviera.
THE NANNY DIARIES, by Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) A satirical look at New Yorkers through the eyes of an East Side nanny.
AN ACCIDENTAL WOMAN, by Barbara Delinsky. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The residents of a quiet New Hampshire town are stunned when a local woman is taken into custody by the F.B.I.
THE EMPEROR OF OCEAN PARK, by Stephen L. Carter. (Knopf, $26.95.) The patriarch of a black family, forced to withdraw from consideration for the Supreme Court, dies under mysterious circumstances.
THE DIVE FROM CLAUSEN'S PIER, by Ann Packer. (Knopf, $24.) A young woman from Wisconsin, whose fianc√© has been rendered a quadriplegic, decides to move to New York and start a new life.
THE SHELTERS OF STONE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $28.95.) Love and danger in a prehistoric society.
HARD EIGHT, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $25.95.) Stephanie Plum takes time out from bounty hunting to search for a girl who has been abducted.
McNALLY'S ALIBI, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $24.95.) A Palm Beach millionaire hires Archy McNally to find a missing manuscript -- the complete text of Truman Capote's novel ''Answered Prayers.''
IN THIS MOUNTAIN, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $25.95.) In the seventh book of the ''Mitford Years'' series, Cynthia Kavanagh thrives in retirement while her husband, Father Tim, grows restless.
GRAVE SECRETS, by Kathy Reichs. (Scribner, $25.) The forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan goes to Guatemala to help families identify their dead.
FIRE ICE, by Clive Cussler with Paul Kemprecos. (Putnam, $26.95.) A mining tycoon tries to overthrow the Russian government.
Weeks
This
Last
On
Week
Week
List
Nonfiction
SLANDER, by Ann Coulter. (Crown, $25.95.) The lawyer and pundit enumerates ''liberal lies about the American right.''
THE LOBSTER CHRONICLES, by Linda Greenlaw. (Hyperion, $22.95.) The author of ''The Hungry Ocean'' gives up swordfishing and moves back in with her parents on the island where she grew up.
TUXEDO PARK, by Jennet Conant. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) The story of Alfred Lee Loomis, a Wall Street tycoon who helped establish a top-secret laboratory at M.I.T. during World War II.
YOU CANNOT BE SERIOUS, by John McEnroe with James Kaplan. (Putnam, $25.95.) The autobiography of the former tennis star and current tennis commentator.
STUPID WHITE MEN, by Michael Moore. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $24.95.) The man behind ''Roger & Me'' takes aim at Republicans and Democrats, corporate America and our ''nation of idiots.''
LUCKY MAN, by Michael J. Fox. (Hyperion, $22.95.) A memoir by the film and television actor, who was told a decade ago that he had Parkinson's disease.
WHY I AM A CATHOLIC, by Garry Wills. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) The author of ''Papal Sin'' explains his beliefs while examining 2,000 years of church history. (+)
JOHN ADAMS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of the country's first vice president and second president.
THE SEXUAL LIFE OF CATHERINE M., by Catherine Millet. (Grove, $23.) A French intellectual recalls her erotic exploits.
THE RIGHT WORDS AT THE RIGHT TIME, edited by Marlo Thomas. (Atria, $25.) More than 100 celebrities describe a turning point in their lives.
SIX DAYS OF WAR, by Michael B. Oren. (Oxford University, $30.) An account of the Arab-Israeli war in 1967 and how it transformed the Middle East.

A MIND AT A TIME, by Mel Levine. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A professor of pediatrics examines the learning patterns of children and the various ways in which parents and other adults can help them succeed.
WEALTH AND DEMOCRACY, by Kevin Phillips. (Broadway, $29.95.) From the Revolutionary War to the turn of the 21st century: a political history of the American rich.
ONCE UPON A TOWN, by Bob Greene. (Morrow, $24.95.) The story of North Platte, Neb., which mil-lions of American servicemen passed through during World War II.
TEN THINGS I LEARNED FROM BILL PORTER, by Shelly Brady. (New World Library, $20.) A memoir of a man with cerebral palsy who worked as a door-to-door salesman in Portland, Ore., for 40 years.
Weeks
This
Last
On
Week
Week
List
Children's Chapter Books
HARRY POTTER AND THE GOBLET OF FIRE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $25.95.) A boy competes against other aspiring wizards. (Ages 10 and up)
THE BAD BEGINNING, by Lemony Snicket. (HarperCollins, $8.95.) The three Baudelaire siblings find misfortune everywhere they turn. (Ages 10 and up)
JUNIE B., FIRST GRADER: BOSS OF LUNCH, by Barbara Park. Illustrated by Denise Brunkus. (Stepping Stone/Random House, $11.95.) A little girl helps out in the school cafeteria. (Ages 4 to 8)
ARTEMIS FOWL: THE ARCTIC INCIDENt, by Eoin Colfer. (Talk Miramax/Hyperion, $16.95.) A young criminal mastermind must team up with his adversaries, the fairies, to save his father. (Ages 12 and up)
THE REPTILE ROOM, by Lemony Snicket. (HarperCollins, $8.95.) The second book in a series about the Baudelaire siblings. (Ages 10 and up)

CORALINE, by Neil Gaiman. Illustrated by Dave McKean. (HarperCollins, $15.99.) After moving into a new apartment house, a young girl unlocks a door to a mysterious and threatening world. (Ages 8 to 12)
HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A boy's life at a school for witchcraft. (Ages 10 and up)
JUNIE B., FIRST GRADER (at LAST!), by Barbara Park. Illustrated by Denise Brunkus. (Stepping Stone/Random House, $11.95.) It's a brand-new school year for a young girl. (Ages 4 to 8)
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A boy returns to witchcraft school. (Ages 10 and up)
LEMONY SNICKET: The Unauthorized Autobiography. (HarperCollins, $11.99.) The enigmatic author tells his life story. (Ages 10 and up)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended July 27, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Best-seller lists for children's picture books, children's chapter books and children's paperbacks, respectively, are published in rotation on succeeding weeks; all three lists appear each week on the Book Review's Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children's titles. Rankings for children's paperbacks do not include serials.
